# failWithError(_:)

**Instance Method**

Signals to this coder that the decode operation has failed.

## Declaration

```swift
func failWithError(_ error: any Error)
```

## Parameters

- **error**: An error that indicates why decoding failed.

## Discussion

Typically, you call this method in your [doc://com.apple.foundation/documentation/Foundation/NSCoding/init(coder:)] implementation. You should set the error when you detect problems such as lack of secure coding, data corruption, or a domain validation failure.

This method is only meaningful to call for decodes.

The effect of calling this method depends on the value of [doc://com.apple.foundation/documentation/Foundation/NSCoder/decodingFailurePolicy-swift.property], as follows:

- If the policy is [doc://com.apple.foundation/documentation/Foundation/NSCoder/DecodingFailurePolicy-swift.enum/raiseException], calling this method throws an exception immediately. Swift code cannot catch this kind of exception.
- If the policy is [doc://com.apple.foundation/documentation/Foundation/NSCoder/DecodingFailurePolicy-swift.enum/setErrorAndReturn], calling this method sets the error property once per call to one of the `decode` methods. Calling it repeatedly has no effect until the call stack unwinds to one of these methodsâ€™ entry points.

## Managing Decode Errors

- **error**: An error in the top-level encode.
